questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Transfusion-related acute lung injury is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), the presentation consists of a sudden-onset respiratory failure, during or soon after a transfusion, along with fever, hypotension, and hypoxemia. Hypertension and raised JVP are usually associated with TACO - transfusion-associated circulatory overload.

Transfusion-related acute lung injury:

  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a severe, frequently fatal complication in which factors in a transfused blood product trigger the activation of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature. (Option A ruled out)
  • Donor-derived antibodies activate recipient neutrophils, which target human leukocyte antigen or human neutrophil antigen.
  • Occurs when blood is transfused from a multiparous female donor or recipient who has undergone repeated blood transfusions. (Option B ruled out)
  • Manifests within 6 hours of transfusion. (Option C ruled out).
  • TRALI usually occurs after transfusion with plasma products, PRP, >>> FFP

Criteria of TRALI

  • Documentation of acute lung injury:
    • Acute onset
    • Hypoxemia
    • Bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray
    • No evidence of circulatory overload
  • No pre-existing acute lung injury before transfusion
  • During or within 6 hours of transfusion
  • No temporal association to an alternative risk factor for acute lung injury.

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload

  • Particularly susceptible are patients with congestive heart failure, pregnant females in 3rd trimester.
  • Patients present with hypertension, raised JVP, pulmonary oedema, and hypoxemia.
  • Lab investigations will show elevated BNP levels.

questions.text: Which type of radiation is commonly used for the irradiation of blood products before transplant surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gamma rays are used for irradiating blood products before transplant surgery as they prevent transfusion-associated graft versus host disease.

  • Gamma rays are electromagnetic waves of very high frequencies which can dissipate energy over a longer, deeper course and produce considerably less damage per unit of tissue.
  • The recommended dose for the irradiation is 2,500 cGy at the centre of the irradiation field, with a minimum dose of 1,500 cGy at any point in the field.
  • Irradiation makes donor T-cells impotent; thus, they do not secrete cytokines and prevent transfusion-associated GVHD.
  • The shelf life of irradiated blood is 28 days.
  • Transfusion-associated GVHD commonly occurs when blood transfusion is done in an immunocompromised person.
  • Reaction typically occurs 10-12 days after transfusion.
  • In transfusion-associated GVHD, pre-text T cells from the donor enter the immunocompromised blood and damage the skin, GIT and liver, resulting in rashes, diarrhoea and jaundice.

Explanation of other options:

Alpha rays (Option A), Beta rays (Option B): Both have very little penetration and cannot be effectively used for irradiating blood products.

X-rays (Option D): X-rays have similar penetration and effects as gamma rays, but are not commonly used for irradiating blood products.

questions.text: Which among the statements regarding the shelf life of blood products are true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cryo-poor plasma has a longer shelf life of 5 years compared to cryoprecipitate. Cryoprecipitate has a shelf life of only 1 year.

Shelf life for various blood components

Explanation of other options:

Platelets have the shortest shelf life (Option A): Among the blood products, platelets have the shortest shelf life of 5-7 days. Viability of platelets is checked by swirling, and they are kept in a platelet agitator to maintain viability.

RBCs stored with SAGM have a longer shelf life than those with CPD-A (Option C): RBCs are stored in blood bags with either SAGM or CPD-A. RBCs stored in SAGM have a shelf life of 42 days, while those in CPD A have a shelf life of 35 days.

Irradiated blood has a shelf life of 28 days (Option D): Irradiated blood is used for transfusion in immunocompromised individuals to prevent transfusion-related GVHD. Irradiated blood has a shelf life of 28 days.

questions.text: The ABO gene is located on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ABO gene, which determines the ABO blood group, resides on chromosome 9at band 2. This gene contains 7 exons.
  • The ABO antigens are expressed on most endothelial and epithelial membranes and are important histocompatibility antigens.
  • The epitopes of ABO antigens are determined by carbohydrates, which are linked either to polypeptides (forming glycoproteins) or to lipids (glycolipids).

Explanation of other options:

Chromosome 1 (Option A): Chromosome 1 has 2 genes which code for the Rh antigens. The gene for Duffy antigen also has its locus is also on chromosome 1, and it gives protection against Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum.

Chromosome 7 (Option B): Kell antigens are encoded by alleles at the KEL locus on chromosome 7, but their production also depends on genes at the KX locus on the X chromosome.

Chromosome 19 (Option C): Chromosome 19 codes for the enzyme L-Fucosyl transferase. This enzyme adds fucose to the oligosaccharides of cells to form the H-antigen. If the L-fucosyl transferase is not produced, it results in the Bombay blood group, which contains anti-A, anti-H and anti-B antibodies in its plasma.

questions.text: While cross-matching blood before a blood transfusion, a major compatibility test is done for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

It requires cross-matching of the donor's red cells, which have the red cell antigens, with the recipient's serum, which has antibodies against those antigens.

  • Antigens are present on the RBC surface, while the plasma has antibodies.
  • ABO grouping is the single most important serological test performed in compatibility testing; consequently, the sensitivity and security of the test system must not be compromised.
  • The fact that anti-A and anti-B are naturally occurring antibodies allows the patient's plasma to be tested against known A and B cells in a reverse group.
  • During cross-matching, donor red blood cells are mixed with the recipient's serum in order to prevent hemolysis and other transfusion-related problems.
  • If an antigen is present, agglutination will occur due to an antigen-antibody reaction.

questions.text: A patient develops fever and chills following a blood transfusion. Which among the following infections is not likely to be transmitted by the blood components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dengue is not usually transmitted via blood transfusion; it's a vector-borne disease.

  • Transfusion-transmitted infections are delayed non-immune transfusion reactions, which occur 24 hrs after transfusion.
  • Viral infections are more common.
  • Advances in donor selection, donor screening, and infectious disease testing have dramatically decreased the incidence of viral transmission by blood products.
  • Testing is done by 4th generation ELISA for HBV, HCV, HIV and syphilis, while for malaria, card tests are used.

questions.text: Following a blood transfusion for anaemia correction, the patient immediately developed chills and rigour. On examination, he was febrile. Which among the following is the most common transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is the most common transfusion reaction.

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction:

  • Most common transfusion reaction
  • Occurs within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Presents with fever > 38°c or more than 1°c rise in temperature, along with chills and rigour
  • Most common causes:
    • Presence of antibodies of the recipient against the leukocytes of the donor blood
    • Storage of blood for a prolonged duration, which results in cytokine release, causing fever

Explanation of other options:

Hemolysis (Option B): Acute intravascular haemolysis can occur, although rarely, as a result of ABO incompatibility.

Transmission of infection (Option C): Transmission of infection through blood transfusion is a delayed non-immune transfusion reaction, occurs after 48 hours.

Electrolyte imbalance (Option D): Electrolyte imbalance, like hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, results from massive transfusion or apheresis and presents with arrhythmias, muscle cramps.

questions.text: Which among the following is an indication of cryoprecipitate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Von Willebrand's disease is a bleeding disorder due to decreased (type 1), absent (type 3), or dysfunctional (type 2) von Willebrand factor.
  • Factor VIII/VWF concentrates are used for managing bleeding episodes.
  • Cryoprecipitate, being rich in vWF and factor VIII, is thus used in Von Willebrand's disease.
  • Cryoprecipitate is derived from fresh frozen plasma by thawing followed by centrifugation and is a source of insoluble plasma proteins, Factor VIII, Factor XII, vWF, and fibrinogen.

Indications for cryoprecipitate:

  • Von Willebrand's disease
  • Hemophilia A
  • Factor XIII deficiency
  • Fibrinogen deficiency

Explanation of other options:

DIC (Option A): Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is characterised by excessive activation of coagulation and the formation of thrombi in the microvasculature. DIC is usually treated with platelet transfusion and FFP; however main concern is treating the underlying cause.

Haemophilia B (Option B): Inherited deficiency of factor IX produces Christmas disease or haemophilia B. Treatment consists of infusion of either FFP or plasma enriched with factor IX.

Severe plasma loss (Option D): Severe plasma loss occurs in polytrauma and burns, which are ideally replaced with crystalloids, FFP.

questions.text: A unit of whole blood collected from a healthy donor was stored in a blood bag containing CPD-A preservative. What is the maximum duration for which this blood can be used for transfusion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The shelf life of RBC when stored in blood bags with CPD A is 35 days.

Shell life of blood products depends on the anticoagulant present.

CPD A is citrate phosphate dextrose adenine and is the most commonly used anticoagulant.

Constituents of CPDA:

  • Citrate: Prevents coagulation by chelating calcium
  • Phosphate: Maintains pH
  • Dextrose: Provides glucose
  • Adenine: Helps in ATP synthesis

questions.text: An individual was identified to have the Bombay blood group. Which among the following antigens and antibodies will be present in his RBC and serum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bombay blood group lacks the antigen on the RBC surface and has anti-A, anti-B, and anti-H antibodies in the plasma.

The Bombay blood group, also known as the hh blood group, is a rare blood type.

Antigen Absence:

  • Individuals with the Bombay phenotype do not express the H antigen(also called substance H), which is typically present in blood group O.
  • As a result, they cannot produce the A antigen(substance A) or the B antigen (substance B) on their red blood cells, regardless of their ABO blood group gene alleles.
  • This absence of A and B antigens makes them universal red blood cell donors within the ABO blood group system.

Anti-H Antibodies:

  • The serum of individuals with the Bombay phenotype contains antibodies that react against all red blood cells of normal ABO phenotypes.
  • These antibodies attack not only A and B antigens but also the H antigen, which is unique to the Bombay group.
  • Consequently, people with this rare blood type can donate blood to any member of the ABO system, but they can only receive blood from other individuals with the Bombay phenotype.

questions.text: A patient with severe blood loss comes for a FFP transfusion. Which blood group plasma can be given without blood grouping and typing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Type AB blood group is the universal plasma donor.
  • People with the AB blood group have both A and B antigens on their RBCs, and neither anti-A nor anti-B antibodies in their plasma.
  • Since they lack these antibodies, their plasma can be safely transfused to recipients of any ABO blood group (A, B, AB, or O). This makes AB-type plasma compatible with all other blood types.
  • In addition to ABO blood groups, there is the Rh factor( Rh+ or Rh-).
  • Rh-negative blood can be given to Rh-negative patients, whereas either Rh+ or Rh- blood may be given to Rh-positive patients.
  • The rules for plasma compatibility are the reverse of red cell compatibility:
    • The universal red cell donor is type O-negative blood group.
    • The universal plasma donor is type AB blood.

Explanation of other options:

O+ (Option A), O- (Option D): O positive blood group will have anti-A and anti-B antibodies in plasma and will agglutinate recipient RBCs if they are A, B or AB blood group.

A+ (Option C): In A+ positive plasma, there are anti-B antibodies that can destroy RBCs if the recipient's blood group is B or AB.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will not result in a positive direct Coombs test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aplastic anaemia is a disorder of pluripotential hematopoietic stem cells that leads to bone marrow failure and does not involve immune-mediated RBC destruction. The direct Coombs test is used to detect immune-mediated hemolysis or RBC destruction.

  • Direct Coombs test (DAT): This test checks for antibodies attached directly to the surface of your red blood cells.
  • Direct Coombs test is positive in:
    • ABO compatibility
    • Screening for blood compatibility before transfusions.
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn
    • Testing for transfusion reactions.
    • Prenatal blood testing.
    • Drug-induced autoimmune haemolytic anaemia
    • Pre-transfusion blood typing.

choices.text: Leukocyte-reduced RBCs are defined by the AABB as having less than 5 x 10⁶ leukocytes in the final component

questions.text: All are true about leukocyte-reduced red blood cell concentrates except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

GVHD is graft versus host disease, and transfusion-related GVHD are prevented by using irradiated blood for transfusion.

  • Leukocyte-reduced RBCs are prepared from whole blood by filtration, and the standard recommendation is to have less than 5 x 10⁶ residual leukocytes. (Option A ruled out)
  • They are prepared using platelet platelet-sparing leukocyte reduction filter.

Indications for leukocyte-reduced red blood cell concentrates:

  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR):
    • FNTR is caused either due to antibodies of the recipient against the leukocytes of the donor blood or cytokines released from donor cells.
    • Since leukocytes are markedly reduced in leukocyte-reduced red blood cell concentrates, the chances of FNHTR are less likely. (Option B ruled out)
  • HLA alloimmunisation
  • TRALI
  • Transfusion-related immunosuppression: Using leukocyte-reduced red blood cell concentrates reduces the risk of transmission of CMV and HIV. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: The minimum platelet count required to donate apheresis platelets is 150,000/μL
AABB Standards limit apheresis platelet donations to no more than twice in 7 days and no more than 24 times per year.

questions.text: All except the following is true for Apheresis Platelet Collections:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During platelet apheresis, citrate is used as an anticoagulant. Citrate chelates calcium, resulting in increased chances of hypocalcemia.

Single donor platelet:

  • Apheresis platelet collections refer to single donor platelets (SDP).
  • These are collected from a single donor using an apheresis machine.
    Approximately 200 mL of platelet-rich plasma is collected from the donor.
    One SDP unit provides an increment of 50,000-60,000 platelets
  • A single SDP unit is equivalent to 6 units of random donor platelets (RDP).
  • Since platelets are collected from a single donor, there is a low risk of immune-mediated reactions, transfusion-transmitted infections. (Option D ruled out).
  • As per standards, a platelet count of a minimum of 150,000/μL and a weight of 50 kg is required for apheresis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Donation interval for apheresis is no more than twice in 7 days and no more than 24 times per year. (Option B ruled out)

Platelet Apheresis Effects of Anticoagulant:

  • Excess anticoagulant goes into the patient's body during platelet apheresis to prevent clotting
  • The anticoagulant can affect the donor's calcium levels, causing hypocalcemia, which is rather common after apheresis
  • One common side effect is a tingling sensation in the lips, which can be counteracted by administering calcium-containing antacid tablets.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the blood group system is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lewis antibodies are primarily IgM and do not cross the placenta. Lewis antibodies have not been implicated in haemolytic disease of the fetus or newborn.

Lewis antigen:

  • Lewis antigens, unlike antigens of all other blood group systems except Chido-Rodgers, are not intrinsic to the RBC but are synthesised in the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Lewis antigens circulate in plasma while bound to glycosphingolipids and are passively adsorbed onto RBC.

Explanation of other options:

ABO antigens are not fully developed at birth (Option B): The A, B and H antigens are detectable early in fetal life but are not fully developed on the red cells at birth. The number of antigen sites reaches 'adult' level at around 1 year of age and remains constant until old age, when a slight reduction may occur.

Serum of Bombay blood group contains potent anti-H in addition to anti-A and anti-B (Option C): Bombay blood group has no antigen to H, A or B, but the plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and anti-H antibodies. This blood can thus be transfused with anyone, while those with the Bombay blood group can be transfused only with the Bombay blood group.

The ABO antigens appear earlier on epithelial cells than on red blood cells (Option D): ABO antigens are expressed on both the RBC surface and epithelial cells. However, they appear earlier on epithelial cells than on RBC during development.

questions.text: Advantages of Autologous Blood Donation are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bacterial contamination of blood can occur at any time during the collection, processing and storage of blood; thus, autologous blood donation will not eliminate the risk of bacterial contamination.

Autologous donors are people with rare blood groups who can donate blood for themselves.
